newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Swedish IT share rally could be nearing its end.
newsitem.headline: Swedish IT share rally could be nearing its end.

text.p: A rally in Swedish information technology (IT) shares could be nearing an end, even though the pace of new IT companies entering the bourse is continuing at a frantic rate, analysts said on Wednesday.
"Sentiment in the Nordic market is euphoric and shares are more than fully valued," an analyst said. "I get frightened when I see how much shares have risen in the past month."
Although there is no index showing how much the sector has risen, analysts estimate it has outperformed the general index's 5.79 percent advance since the start of the year.
Last year, IT shares doubled in value, analysts said, outdoing a general index jump of 38 percent.
Now analysts say the sector could be overheating. Some expect the whole sector to slide, while others see investors becoming more selective.
With only a few IT shares on the bourse, investors hoping for substantial growth have been scrambling to lay their hands on them, pushing prices higher.
"They are investing for the future when traditional computing will merge with media and television," Karl-Mikael Syding, analyst at Swedish bank Swedbank, told Reuters.
Last year 10 IT companies were listed on the bourse and another eight have said they are in the starting blocks.
Three of them, Alfaskop Partners AB, Office AB and Entra Data AB, announced on Tuesday they would seek listings.
A fourth, computer consulting company Sigma AB, will present a prospectus on Thursday for its February 21 introduction, an analyst said.
"It is understandable that the companies take the chance to introduce themselves on the bourse because they can get as much money that way as they could earn over 20 years," Syding said.
He said many IT companies had a price/earnings (p/e) ratio of 20. Syding was fairly optimistic about current price levels, but was cautious about further increases.
"A bubble (which will burst) will be created sooner or later, but not yet," Syding said.
"Those looking at the sector have lost the sense of correct valuation and they do not know when a bubble starts to build."
Regarding the newcomers, Entra looks almost fully valued with a p/e of 20 on 1997 profits, while posting a 12 percent profit margin in 1995, Syding said.
Alfaskop seems cheap at a p/e of about 12 but Office will be listed without the best bits.
Of the companies already listed, some analysts say they believe in WM-Data, which offers computer network building, software, eduction and support. But others said it was overvalued.
"WM-Data's share should be 40 percent lower," an analyst said.
Other share prices should be cut by 50 percent, analysts said. Among this group is Verimation AB, a company making products which enable different computer brands to communicate, according to Syding.
He said, however, rival Frontec was too cheap.
"While Verimation markets its product on its technical abilities, Frontec offers to solve a problem for companies with its product," he said.
